story:
Thursday, Feb. 20, 2014
End of Phase One of My Campaign

Thanks to all who've contributed to this project thus far through Indie-gogo. Please note that there's no disappointment in the amount raised thus far, even though it's short of the more ambitious original goal. Some crowdfunding sites are all or nothing, that's not the case with this site, and all funds will come my way. And the opportunity is still open for you to contribute through this site.

Although I was set back a bit in the early days of this campaign by some unexpected minor crises in my life that prevented me from pulling out all of the stops in this first effort, I'm committed to moving forward with this project with more enthusiasm than ever. My list of people whose stories I hope to include has increased threefold. And thanks to the response I've received, including pledges of significant future financial support, and some new collaborations, I believe in this project's value now more than ever.

By this weekend, I'll be posting plans for the next phase of this project. If you're late in seeing this, please do read on, and consider making a contribution, or helping me further spread the word. Thanks again!


One Person Can Still Make a Difference.  Coming Together in a Spirit of Supportive Community, We Can Do Even More.

Please support my new book,

"Voices of Conscience and Courage."

Please consider a donation of $5, $10, $25 or more as you read on!


My name is John Quinlan.  I'm a Madison, Wisconsin-based writer, historian, civil rights advocate, community activist, and radio show host. I've met and interviewed countless amazing dedicated folks working on the cutting edge of social change, and I'm writing to ask for your help in bringing their inspiring voices to a larger audience.  I believe that it's the underlying life stories of ordinary people that move and inspire people to action, and that reveal the interconnections of all of the great movements for social justice.

This book, an anthology of remarkable life stories, represents a powerful way to get those deeper stories out into the world, as a means of inspiring others to action.

Storytelling that evokes the courage and integrity of principled individuals has always been one of the most powerful forces for social change.  And when I interview someone, it's just as important for me to find out why someone does what they do, as it is to explain what it is they've done.  A few examples of those people whose stories will be told in this book are featured below.  

Over the years, I’ve had the opportunity to interview and come to know some amazing people who’ve had the courage to reach deep inside themselves to do the right thing. 

  • Some are folks who’ve shared difficult life stories, so that others can achieve understandings that will turn back stigma. 
  • Others are people who’ve had the courage to speak out on matters of principle, in defense of human rights or democracy, even in a climate of fear that puts them at great risk. 
  • Some are storytellers themselves willing to take the steps necessary give voice to people long denied a voice, even if it makes them vulnerable to criticism or physical harm. 
  • Others are folks whose perseverance and imagination have helped drive and sustain the movements for civil rights, women’s rights, disability rights, and LGBT rights. 
  • Some are spiritual leaders willing to put their faith into action. 
  • Then there folks who are unafraid to stand up to the powers-that-be in their defense of the environment. 
  • Still others have advocated for commonsensical political reform and the communitarian role that is the realm of good government, at the risk of being blacklisted and ridiculed, or being told what they want is not in keeping with the popular will of the moment.

Social change does not come easily, but these are folks willing to persevere, become personally vulnerable, and weather hardship on the path to justice, despite the conventional wisdom that they can't succeed.  On the one hand, they're a pretty extraordinary group of people.  On the other hand, these are ordinary people, not all that different than you and me.  What they can do, we can do, too.

Wisconsin Capitol, February 2011                                             Photos: Callen Harty

Three years ago this month, hundreds of thousands of ordinary people from all over Wisconsin, and all walks of life, came to their state capitol in support of quality education, workers' rights, and open government in the face of the destructive and undemocratic actions of a newly-elected governor.  Some of my stories are those of people connected to this movement, as I explore with them the life stories that led the individuals behind this movement to take such a courageous stand, and where their experiences have taken them since.

The connections between my book and the 2011 and 2012 Wisconsin Uprising is described here, in the Voices of Conscience and Courage blog.   But, as noted above, the stories I'm hoping to tell span a much broader range of issues and time, and involve people of many different ages and backgrounds.  Most stories are rooted here in Wisconsin, but play themselves out across the nation and the world.


The obstacles facing people of conscience and courage are daunting.  In every major movement for social justice, it's always been this way.  However, we can draw hope, even when we're being bombarded with messages that tell us that there's no hope.  As so many of us learned in the context of the Wisconsin Uprising, we need to counter short-sighted and distorted media messages by being the catalyst for alternative storytelling of an authentic kind.

We were reminded last year in celebrating the 50th anniversary of the 1963 March on Washington, people who put their beliefs into action, who have the courage and strength to persevere, do make a difference over time.  Such are the lessons of history made by folks who've lived and still live among us.  Such will be the lesson of the Wisconsin Uprising, and such will be the path we take as a nation and a world if we simply keep building on all we've done, and resolving to creatively keep doing it.

This is the kind of multi-faceted storytelling I'm taking on with this book, based on my strengths as an interviewer skilled in the art of giving people a comfortable space in which to tell their own stories, and the insights that have come with several decades of my own activism.  It bears repeating:  in these times, we need and deserve to be inspired by the words and deeds of others.  It's times like these when it's now more important than ever for people of conscience and courage to reach out to each other as a means of finding new and innovative ways to make our voices heard.  


That's what this book is all about--giving some ordinary yet ultimately extraordinary people a forum in which they can tell their own life stories. As you can see by my bio, that's long been a focus of my own work.  As you'll see from some of the examples of people who'll I'll be writing about below (a list that's by no means complete, and is growing every day), there are a lot of largely untold stories to tell, that I hope will inspire folks to make a difference themselves.

However, I can't do it without your help.

Please consider a donation of $5, $10, $25 or more.  (Larger donations will also reserve you a copy of the book.)  Please scroll down to the bottom of this page for an easy way to donate via credit card or paypal.

I'd also appreciate your help in getting out the word by sharing this page with your friends in the social media.

With your help, these efforts will form the foundation for a much larger and sustainable multimedia public education campaign--reminding folks of all that they can do, working individually and in supportive community--for many years to come....  Please consider using sending a donation today via the link at the top of the page, where you can contribute via credit card or paypal.  Working together, we can make a difference!

Pictured just outside our community radio studio with my longtime friend and colleague, Charlie Daniel, recipient of both the city of Madison's ML King Award, and its James C. Wright Human Rights Award.  Like many of those whose stories will be featured in my book, her activism has spanned multiple issues, including civil rights, LGBT rights, and culturally competent health strategies for communities of color.  In particular, her outspoken leadership in creating support for LGBT youth of color has had a powerful effect in our community.  Ten years ago, I shared this memorable radio conversation with Charlie (edited down to five minutes), reflective of her belief in young people, and the affinity and passion she feels for them. 

The arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends toward justice. 

-- Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.


Immediately below are three representative examples of some of the individuals who will be featured in the book, folks who've been of all generations, and from a diversity of backgrounds and cultures, working on issues of racial and economic justice, LGBT rights, women's rights, disability rights, the environment, and much, much more. 

Embracing, Art, Heart, and Activism: Giving Voice to Our Youth

When Sol Kelley-Jones was 10-years-old back in 1997, she was among the first children of lesbian and gay parents in Madison, Wisconsin's schools.  It wasn't always easy.  She was taunted by some, and also physically harassed, including being pushed down the stairs at her school. But she didn't retreat into a corner.  In experiencing the pain that came with those experiences of rejection and harassment, she reasoned that it came out of a basic lack of understanding.  And, in fourth and fifth grade, she paved the way for others by designing a curriculum that showcased LGBT role models and other positive messages about our families, and she testified at legislative hearings and other public settings, sharing her family's story, and making headlines statewide and beyond.  At age 12, she spoke before a half million people on the Mall in Washington, and began to receive attention in the national media, and awards from national social justice groups.  At 13, Sol and gay community leader Callen Harty co-founded Proud Theater, an award-winning multi-cultural youth theater company, featuring original works based on its young members' lives, still going strong today.  Over the years, her activism broadened and evolved to include issues of basic civil liberties alongside civil rights, as she helped lead high school students citywide to protest government excesses in the face of 9/11, and her work has always included a strong awareness of the need to support and empower young people of color.  

Today, at age 27, her activism encompasses the full spectrum of social justice issues, resonant with a personal mission of finding ways to link "art, heart, and activism."  Her studies at Hampshire College took her to internships in the West Bank and along the US-Mexican border, and upon her return, she produced a powerful play, "The birds that are your hands: how to start a fire under siege" about the experiences of young people living life in the shadow of a wall.  While at Hampshire, she pioneered ways to apply dramatic techniques in ways that healed and informed people on the path to social justice.  Her work has since taken her all over the US, to the Middle East and recently to East Africa, where she therapeutically infuses art and drama in powerful ways that lift up young people and others facing trauma and prejudice. Her multi-faceted work continues at Proud Theater and multiple other venues, launching young people down the road to the realization of their greatest dreams.  Sol was recently honored on a CNN Headline News feature on Everyday Heroes.

While Sol's early story was told more than a decade ago in six books, in newspaper venues ranging from the Chicago Tribune to the Los Angeles Times, in People Magazine, on public radio, and virtually every major television network, the totality of her recent story, and how her early history has influenced her activism as an adult, has never been told in one place before.  As someone who has been "Uncle John" to Sol for all of her life, she's trusting me to tell that story now.

A Compassionate Vision for a More Sustainable World

Soon after Gene and Linda Farley had been married and both had become doctors in the 1950s, they moved with their young family from upstate New York to the Navajo Nation, where they helped bring medical care to thousands. They took what they learned, and, upon their return to New York, Gene took steps that led to the founding of the discipline of "family medicine," a holistic medical approach that brings in family and community as partners on the path to healing now practiced by over 100,000 doctors worldwide.  In 1963, they took the life-changing step of attending the March on Washington, reaffirming a lifelong commitment to racial and economic justice. 

Their love for one another was inseparable from their love of the Earth and all of its inhabitants, and in recent years, they founded the Farley Center for Peace, Justice and Sustainability as a means of promoting good health, sustainable and health food practices, and a spirit of stewardship toward the Earth.  Linda left us four years ago and Gene in early November, and hundreds of folks came together recently at the celebration of Gene's life to mark the difference they'd made in our lives.  Click here for a link to an essay I wrote about Gene in the Madison Times, and click here for a link to a special radio show tribute I produced honoring Gene and Linda back in November.

Teaching Younger Generations Why Voting Rights Matter

While she may have grown up knowing and learning from Dr. King, for whom she has great respect, Joanne Bland also knows that it was ordinary children and women like herself who formed the foundation of the black civil rights movement.  When she was was 11, she and her teenage sister experienced firsthand the carnage of Bloody Sunday, in the context of the 1965 Selma to Montgomery March for voting rights.  At that young age, she'd already been arrested 13 times for civil disobedience.  Initially facing down violent Alabama troupers by standing their ground with non-violence, she and her 14-year-old sister found themselves retreating to a nearby car amidst the bloody aftermath of the day's events. As they both cried tears of anguish, she felt a dampness coming down from her 14-year-old sister's brow, and realized that it was not her sister's tears, but her blood. The incident shook a nation who saw it all play out on the national news. 

Dr. King came to town a short time later, joined by thousands of allies of all colors and creeds from around the US, a court order was obtained, and soon Joanne and her sister found themselves crossing the Edmund Pettus Bridge on the road to Montgomery, in a march that would lead a few months later to President Johnson's signing of the 1965 Voting Rights Act. 

In 1992, she co-founded Selma's grasssroots National Voting Rights Museum to chronicle the role of ordinary people in that movement, and a few years later, she began yearly treks to Wisconsin to teach our young people about this important history. In turn, dozens of these Wisconsin young people have followed Joanne down South, where they were a vital force in building her museum. 


I first met Joanne on a trip to Selma in August 2006 with my friend, the Rev. Darrell Richey (at left in back row in photo), where we assisted with oral history projects and where I broadcast a live three hour version of my show from her museum.  There, in addition to Joanne, we met other Selma veterans, like Lawrence and Dorothea Huggins, who'd been teachers at the time of the March. In recent months, Lawrence had developed the only color footage of the March from film canisters that had been in storage for 40 years, which he proudly showed to us. After meeting Joanne, I was hooked, and I became part of the long history of Wisconsinites called to assist her in her important work, and had the privilege of being with her in Selma, and then Madison, as we viewed together first the nomination,then the inauguration, of this country's first African-American president.  I learned quickly, that dozens of young people have had their lives changed in knowing Ms. Bland, as we documented on my radio show in a tribute to the inspiring influence she's had on them.

Today, in this era of renewed race-based voter suppression and a recent Supreme Court decision that gutted the Voting Rights Act, Joanne's fight continues. US Senator Tammy Baldwin counts her visit to Joanne's museum in the company of Georgia US Rep. John Lewis eight years ago as one of the most inspiring such visits in her life.  Joanne followed and supported developments at the WI Capitol closely, and then US Rep. Baldwin also noted this resonance of movements in a speech at the Capitol delivered on the 44th anniversary of the Selma March.  Both of their stories are told in this video I produced in March of 2011, enitled Historic Resonances Between Madison and Selma, juxtaposing the powerful story-telling of two women who have both been civil rights pioneers.

Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world. Indeed, it is the only thing that ever has.

Margaret Mead


Here are some other folks whose stories I'll be previewing for you, in days to come in the Voices of Conscience and Courage blog:


Inspiring Others on the Path to Peace and Justice

  Former State Rep. Midge Miller is a political folk hero in her home state of Wisconsin, but the national role she played as a feminist leader and peace advocate may be less well-known.  As I learned on a special memorial edition of my radio show, as an advocate for women's rights, she was a contemporary of Friedan, Steinem, and Abzug, and her Madison colleague, NOW co-founder, Kathryn Clarenbach.  As an advocate for peace, she convinced her good friend, Minnesota Senator Eugene McCarthy, to run for president in 1968 as a means of advancing a peaceful solution in Vietnam. The candidacy that she spearheaded is widely seen as the development that caused President Lyndon Johnson not to run for another term. 


Throughout a distinguished career in the state legislature alongside colleagues like Mary Lou Munts and later Rebecca Young, she helped revitalize the WI Democratic party as a force for social justice.  In later years, her work with the Madison Institute, the WI Network for Peace and Justice, and in other realms formed the foundation for a lasting legacy.  Shortly before she passed away in 2009 after a courageous fight with cancer, her daughter-in-law recorded almost a dozen hours of videotaped interviews with her that have not yet been shared with the public.  Midge's son Mark (whose work is described below) has given me permission to use these interviews as a basis for a chapter in my book, and this will be the catalyst for efforts to share the tapes themselves more widely.  Eventually, we'd like to expand this project to include the stories of other politically active women who left their mark on Madison and the nation.  Again, your generous support will help to make this happen!

Young Photographer's Amazing Work Inspires 

Awareness and Action

  While 22-year-old Jenna Pope's activism is evocative of the powerful politicization of young women and men that occurred in the wake of the 2011 and 2012 protest at the Wisconsin Capitol, her motivation for becoming involved in rooted in the legacy of two earlier generations.  She first decided to march, and then live in the US Capitol, out of her love and respect for her mother, a lifelong teacher in her hometown of Edgerton.  Very quickly, her burgeoning talents as a photographer took wing, and her photos became some of the most personally compelling and evocative of the Capitol protests. She was a frequent guest on my radio show, as documented in this special video edition here. Her mother was immensely proud of her work, and saw it expand to Jenna's award-winning coverage of Occupy Wall Street and other protest movements worldwide. Two years ago, Jenna experienced the loss of both her mother and her beloved grandmother in the space of a few short weeks.  With the support of her father and other family members, she has transformed her grief into a new resolve to use her photographs and dispatches as a means of educating people about the nature of social justice protests around the world, including trips this past summer to Turkey's Taksim Square. 

This fall, she launched a crowdfunding project on Indiegogo, raising almost $20,000 for her new book "Jenna Pope: An Activist Armed with a Camera," due out later this month.  See JennaPope.com .  Both Jenna and I are blessed with hundreds and hundreds of folks who follow our work on Facebook and elsewhere, as activist-journalists.  Jenna's success is part of what encouraged me to think outside of the box and find a way to make this book project self-sustaining.  Please believe me in me, too, and consider making a contribution!

A Cultural Translator Paving the Way for Latino LGBT People

Since moving to Madison from his native Ecuador in 2002, Diego Campoverde-Cisneros has made a major mark on our community as both a broadcaster at La Movida, Madison's Spanish-language radio station, and in his work in the larger community.  A leader in efforts to create community for LGBT people of color, he is a co-founder of Alianza Latina, an LGBT support group.  In 2013, he received the "Alix Olson Social Justice Award," named after a highly-respected longtime openly lesbian Madison police detective, presented by STAJOH, the coalition she co-founded to counter hate crimes and hate groups locally. As Alix herself noted, it was a fitting honor for this young man who has done so much to build bridges and increase understandings in our community.

There is No Normal:  Honoring Cognitive Diversity


   Unlike some of the other people who's stories I'll be telling, Jonathan Mooney is not from Wisconsin, although he has spent extensive time as a consultant working with the University of Wisconsin-Madison's School of Education.  More than almost anyone else I've had the privilege of interviewing over the years, my conversations with Jonathan moved me in ways that continue to give me almost daily personal insights, and further inform my world view.  He's the author of "The Short Bus: A Journal Beyond Normal."

Saddled with the labels "ADHD" and "dyslexia" at an early age, Jonathan at 13 was a special ed student who still couldn't read.  And yet, less than a decade later, he received an English Lit degree from  prestigious Brown University, graduating with honors.  His journey might have stopped there, self-defined as how he had overcome all of the shortcomings and failures of his younger self.  But instead, a few years later, Jonathan embarked on an incredible odyssey of discovery--traveling cross-country, in a short bus, no less--as a means of meeting other young people coping with the challenges and unfair judgements that come with labels connected with cognitive and emotional disability, not unlike his 13-year-old younger self.  Expecting at first to be in a position to provide these young people with comfort and insights, instead, he discovered that it was these young people who had so much to teach him.  Soon he learned that the key to his own self-realization was not to reject his younger self, but to embrace who he was at the core of his being.

His book has particular resonance with young people who have been labeled as developmentally disabled or extremely gifted, who just don't fit into the "one-size-fits-all" approach adopted by many schools, but it also has lessons for us all.  Among the memorable truths Jonathan imparts is that it's usually "dysteachia," not dyslexia, that lies at the root of young person's challenges.  He is an advocate for our society's embrace of the concept of "cognitive diversity," with broad implications for its importance as a new way of viewing individual rights, and weighing the horrible consequences when we attempt to establish arbitrary standards for what constitutes "normal."  A definition of disability can often be reframed and reconsidered as part of the richness of the diversity of human experience, with worth beyond measure.  Aside from its applications in terms of creativity, it also has more practical applications.  For example, a recent study revealed that more than 60 percent of the student body of M.I.T.  could be considered to be "learning disabled," by testing standards that ignore the value of individual difference.

Jonathan has become an inspirational speaker and educational consultant who has touched thousands of lives through his work.  Never one to take himself too seriously, his narratives contain a playful and highly irreverent element that's ultimately endearing. His admonition to young people to join him on a revolution against all that is normal, is actually represents quite a serious quest.  Based today out of Santa Monica, California, his latest social venture is a social project called "Streetcraft LA," which works with at risk youth, street hustlers, tag bangers, supporting them in becoming creative economy volunteers.

Have You Been to Jail for Justice:  Taking a Stand

   Damon Terrell, president of the Autonomous Solidarity Organization, was an active participant in the Wisconsin Protests.  Singled out and brutally arrested in August 2013 by the Capitol police while participating in the Solidarity Singalong, the police's excesses were captured on videotape.  He endured jail and the threat of a felony prosecution for the cause he believed in.  Still he had to ask himself:  why did the police choose to single him out?


Standing on Principle Even in a Time of Fear

       While serving on the Madison School Board in the days immediately following 9/11, Bill Keys refused to bend to the will of the mob in refusing to force students to say the Pledge of Allegiance.  It's one of many stands of conscience he and his wife Linda have taken over the years for countless causes, including mental health consumer rights, racial and economic justice, and LGBT rights.  I met Bill and Linda as they did tireless service on a powerful and broad coalition that came together to persuade the local United Way to discontinue funding the Boy Scouts as along as they continued to discriminate against gay Scouts and gay Scout leaders.  Here he stands in front of a Hmong wall hanging at a benefit for Kasjiab House, a group founded to alleviate the trauma facing Hmong elders as a resonant result of the Vietnam War.

A History-Making Nurse Who Educates and Spreads Understandings

Barbara Nichols's history-making firsts include being the first African-American woman to serve as the head of the National Nurse's Association, and the first African-American woman to serve as a member of the governor's cabinet.  In recent years, she's traveled the world recruiting international healthcare workers for needed positions in the US.  As a result, she has a remarkable range of insights about the professional and multi-culturally competent management of organizations in the private, public and nonprofit sectors, particularly in the area of healthcare. While officially retired, she's a speaker in much demand at colleges and universities across the country, who have given her almost a dozen honorary degrees over the years.  She currently serves as the president of the Dane County chapter of the UN Association-USA.


Living Out the Cause of Peace

Joseph and Joann Elder are community treasures, with a long history of action on behalf of the creation of a peace-filled world, resonant with their Quaker faith.  In addition to distinguished service for sixty years as a UW Sociology and South Asian faculty member, he has mediated disputes in venues like Vietnam and Afghanistan.  She has advised countless young people as the longtime advisor for the Sociology Department, and helped to found the local chapter of PFLAG (Parents, Family and Friends of LGBT people).  Together they serve on countless community boards and UW committees.  Look for my article in an upcoming dispatch in the Voices of Conscience and Courage blog.


Faith in Action Means Being Willing to Put It All on the Line

  Gene Matthews is a longtime friend of my father, who met him at the airport in Seoul, South Korea 60 years ago as they both embarked on a short term Methodist missions program.  In recent years, he's also become one of my best friends, and favorite people.  While he had met me as an infant, I next saw Gene almost fifty years later, just following my father's death in June 2010, and he gave me countless insights into my father's path as a young man.  Gene married his wife Insook and remained in South Korea until retirement, joining a group of missionaries of diverse faiths in standing up to brutally oppressive military regimes, risking death, imprisonment and deportation.  A culmination of this work was their support of eight men who'd been wrongly accused of treason, and then summarily executed.  They were allied with human rights advocate Kim Dae Jung--himself the near victim of several assassination attempts--who eventually became president of South Korea in 1997.  Gene and George Ogle (another missionary friend of my dad's, who earned both his master's and doctoral degrees at the University of Wisconsin) were invited to to the new president's inaugural, and then were given one of South Korea's highest honors for their courageous human rights work.  All of this is chronicled in a remarkable book called "More Than Witnesses," for which I produced a special event at the October 2010 Wisconsin Book Festival.  See this blog I created, that chronicles the event, the story behind it, and the media associated with it. 


Promoting Social Justice and Community

Gladis Benavides (left) is a close friend and colleague, who has become like family to me.  Born in Brazil, and raised in Peru on a ranch located just a short hike from Macchu Picchu, her ancestors included a Peruvian president, and her father was a former mayor of Lima.  As a teen she attended the Sorbonne, briefly lived in Morocco, and then at 19, she moved to Madison.  Soon becoming a single mother of two, her life circumstances were considerably different than those she'd grown up with, but she loved her new home and her new friends, and was determined to make life in Madison work.  Over many years, she honed her skills as a tireless advocate--becoming a highly-respected state and municipal employee in the field of equal opportunity, and then an accomplished workplace trainer and consultant--helping organizations to become culturally competent, how to understand and observe equal opportunity laws, and how to avoid workplace conflict. She is a respected truthspeaker on matters of racial and economic justice, and it's been my privilege to work closely with her in recent years.  Few people I know epitomize as she does the notion of being a voice of conscience and courage.

Barbara McKinney (right) moved to Madison from St. Louis to take care of her beloved son Mike, who died eight years ago.  Mike McKinney was a TV anchor universally respected both for his integrity as a journalist and his tireless community service, in particular his work on behalf of the Second Harvest Food Bank, and AIDS Network.  Barbara elected to stay in Madison, and she soon became the associate director of the Madison Urban Ministry.  Though known at first as "Mike's mom," Barbara quickly became a respected leader in her own right in the area of restorative justice, and for her tireless work on behalf of numerous community boards.   


San Franciscan's Storytelling and Activism Knows No Bounds

 Joanie Juster lives in San Francisco, but is considered by many to be an honorary Wisconsinite.  Less than a week after the onset of protests at the Wisconsin Capitol, she'd purchased a one way ticket to Madison and was living amidst the diverse group of citizens who occupied the Capitol.  She first became familiar with Wisconsin while doing research for an award-winning documentary film entitled "Alaska Far and Away," which airs periodically on PBS stations nationwide.  The film chronicles the migration of Upper Midwesterners during the Great Depression to the Matanuska Valley of Alaska, seeking a better life.  Joanie has a long history of working on behalf of social justice, and is an esteemed ally of the Bay Area's LGBT community.  Her activism includes being an early supporter of the NAMES Project Quilt, where she worked closely with her good friend Cleve Jones (founder of the Quilt, and an early associate of Harvey Milk.)  During a recent display of the Quilt on the National Mall in DC, Joanie was interviewed by Smithsonian Institution researchers about its early history.  Her current project is a film on the life of Sister Simone Campbell.  Joanie has returned to Wisconsin several times in recent years.  While disappointed in the outcome of the June 2012 recall election, she believes that the citizens who came together in protest will eventually prevail.  And she'll be right there, standing beside us.


Love Conquers All

Mark Miller and Jo Oyama-Miller have long worked together as a team on behalf of social justice.  (Mark is the son of Midge Miller, mentioned above, and Jo is a second generation Japanese-American whose family was sent to internment camps in World War II.)  Married in 1968 just following the Supreme Court's "Loving v. Virginia" case, which struck down the prohibition in many southern states against interracial marriage, they first lived in Selma, where Mark was stationed as an Air Force pilot.  In a memorable 2006 interview on my radio show, Mark explained how that personal experience had made him realize that "two people who love each other should never be denied the right of marriage."  

As a leader in the State Senate, Mark was one of 14 Democratic senators to leave the state as a means of delaying passage of draconian bills without process by their GOP counterparts.  Jo has a long history of community service, including her tenure at the Community Action Coalition. They, too, have long been voices of conscience and courage in Madison.


The Compassionate Critic

                 


In March of 2006, I interviewed Roger Ebert, in the context of the Wisconsin Film Festival.  it was one of the last interviews he would conduct before losing his voice during cancer surgery a short time later.  Despite this, the highly-principled Ebert found other ways to express himself, and continued to be a prolific writer until his death last year.  On this occasion, we had a spirited discussion about the history of the depiction of LGBT community leaders in film.  Our conversation was resonant with his overall belief, Infused throughout Ebert's film criticism, that this powerful medium can overcome its shortcomings, and be a powerful force for social change.   Roger Ebert is one of a handful of "famous" people I'll be covering in my book.  However, I strongly believe that he belongs here as someone who understood the responsibility that comes with notoriety, and who remained an accessible and compassionate advocate for all human beings throughout his lifetime.

Transforming A LIfe of Challenge into the 

Promise of a Better Life for Others

Karen Ott Avery, who passed away unexpectedly in late October of last year at the age of 51, was one of my dearest friends.  She'd faced an unimaginably difficult childhood,  and she was forced to live on her own at age 12. In becoming a single mom at age 16, she resolved that her own children would have a better life, and she delivered on that promise.  "Transformative" is a word that describes her well, as someone who took difficult and sometimes painful life lessons and made them into something life-giving and empowering of others facing resonant struggles.  When I first got to know her, she was in her mid-20s, a mature and wise young woman, who was an effective leader of our newly-formed Fair Housing Council (where she was director, and I was board president). 

The friendship grew strong over the years.  She was someone whose enthusiasm was infectious, whose sense of humor was generously applied, and who knew how to bring out the best in everyone she was around.  She worked tirelessly for racial justice at both our council and Milwaukee Fair Housing.  In 1998, she became the associate director of the large Milwaukee disability rights agency, Independence First.  She spoke out often about her own experiences with emotional disability, and helped found the Grassroots Empowerment Project, an agency that provides a framework of support for mental health consumers statewide. Karen never wanted to be the center of attention in the public eye, but nonetheless, she inspired others through her tireless and facilitative leadership. She was a great friend, as hundreds of folks affirmed at her memorial service through countless stories of how she'd made a difference in our lives. 

Karen's last year of life was extremely rough for her, as resonant traumas from her childhood and youth came back to haunt her, and her physical health began deterioriating.  She is at peace now, and her legacy lives on in the lives of her beloved family, and the countless friends whose lives she's touched.

It's in Karen's memory that I dedicate this book.

****

There are a variety of premia available at different levels of giving listed in the boxes at right.  Any amount will appreciated, and will be a further catalyst for future support by others!  (That's the nature of a site like indiegogo.)  

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Please help me to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Toward that end, be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools on this site.

If you have questions, please drop me a note at John.L.Quinlan at gmail dot com, and thanks in advance for your support of this important project, shining a light on folks whose devotion to social justice is making a difference in this world each and every day.

*********

 And so, in conclusion, we return to that important question of what one person can do, and how we find the courage to do it.

The African American science fiction writer Octavia Butler, writing about her history-making friend Shirley Chisholm, wrote: 
"The idea is that people are fearless, and that's why they're taking action.  I think that it's more important to realize that they're terrified, and they're still taking action, that they know exactly what they're risking, and they still risk it."

Below:  Callen Harty had a deep-seated fear of singing in public.  But early in 2011, he began a tradition of journeying to the cavernous Rotunda of the WI State Capitol, and proudly belting out a powerful solo rendition of "We Shall Overcome." It was an ongoing means of supporting the pro-workers' rights, pro-education, pro-democracy movement taking place there. He was afraid, but he simply put one foot in front of the other and made it happen.  Callen's is among dozens of stories of people working for social change that will be told in my new book, "Voices of Conscience and Courage."

Please considering supporting this effort in any way you can, through your financial contribution, or by helping spread the word.   Thanks!
