Thursday, Feb. 20, 2014
End of Phase One of My Campaign

Thanks to all who've contributed to this project thus far through Indie-gogo.  Please note that there's no disappointment in the amount raised thus far, even though it's short of the more ambitious original goal. Some crowdfunding sites are all or nothing, that's not the case with this site, and all funds will come my way.  And the opportunity is still open for you to contribute through this site.

Although I was set back a bit in the early days of this campaign by some unexpected minor crises in my life that prevented me from pulling out all of the stops in this first effort, I'm committed to moving forward with this project with more enthusiasm than ever. My list of people whose stories I hope to include has increased threefold.  And thanks to the response I've received, including pledges of significant future financial support, and some new collaborations, I believe in this project's value now more than ever.

By this weekend, I'll be posting plans for the next phase of this project.  If you're late in seeing this, please do read on, and consider making a contribution, or helping me further spread the word. Thanks again!

One Person Can Still Make a Difference.  Coming Together in a Spirit of Supportive Community, We Can Do Even More.Please support my new book, "Voices of Conscience and Courage."Please consider a donation of $5, $10, $25 or more as you read on!
My name is John Quinlan.  I'm a Madison, Wisconsin-based writer, historian, civil rights advocate, community activist, and radio show host. I've met and interviewed countless amazing dedicated folks working on the cutting edge of social change, and I'm writing to ask for your help in bringing their inspiring voices to a larger audience.  I believe that it's the underlying life stories of ordinary people that move and inspire people to action, and that reveal the interconnections of all of the great movements for social justice.This book, an anthology of remarkable life stories, represents a powerful way to get those deeper stories out into the world, as a means of inspiring others to action.
Storytelling that evokes the courage and integrity of principled individuals has always been one of the most powerful forces for social change.  And when I interview someone, it's just as important for me to find out why someone does what they do, as it is to explain what it is they've done.  A few examples of those people whose stories will be told in this book are featured below.  Over the years, I’ve had the opportunity to interview and come to know some amazing people who’ve had the courage to reach deep inside themselves to do the right thing. 
Some are folks who’ve shared difficult life stories, so that others can achieve understandings that will turn back stigma. 
Others are people who’ve had the courage to speak out on matters of principle, in defense of human rights or democracy, even in a climate of fear that puts them at great risk. 
Some are storytellers themselves willing to take the steps necessary give voice to people long denied a voice, even if it makes them vulnerable to criticism or physical harm. 
Others are folks whose perseverance and imagination have helped drive and sustain the movements for civil rights, women’s rights, disability rights, and LGBT rights. 
Some are spiritual leaders willing to put their faith into action. 
Then there folks who are unafraid to stand up to the powers-that-be in their defense of the environment. 
Still others have advocated for commonsensical political reform and the communitarian role that is the realm of good government, at the risk of being blacklisted and ridiculed, or being told what they want is not in keeping with the popular will of the moment.

Social change does not come easily, but these are folks willing to persevere, become personally vulnerable, and weather hardship on the path to justice, despite the conventional wisdom that they can't succeed.  On the one hand, they're a pretty extraordinary group of people.  On the other hand, these are ordinary people, not all that different than you and me.  What they can do, we can do, too.
Wisconsin Capitol, February 2011                                             Photos: Callen Harty
Three years ago this month, hundreds of thousands of ordinary people from all over Wisconsin, and all walks of life, came to their state capitol in support of quality education, workers' rights, and open government in the face of the destructive and undemocratic actions of a newly-elected governor.  Some of my stories are those of people connected to this movement, as I explore with them the life stories that led the individuals behind this movement to take such a courageous stand, and where their experiences have taken them since.The connections between my book and the 2011 and 2012 Wisconsin Uprising is described here, in the Voices of Conscience and Courage blog.   But, as noted above, the stories I'm hoping to tell span a much broader range of issues and time, and involve people of many different ages and backgrounds.  Most stories are rooted here in Wisconsin, but play themselves out across the nation and the world.The obstacles facing people of conscience and courage are daunting.  In every major movement for social justice, it's always been this way.  However, we can draw hope, even when we're being bombarded with messages that tell us that there's no hope.  As so many of us learned in the context of the Wisconsin Uprising, we need to counter short-sighted and distorted media messages by being the catalyst for alternative storytelling of an authentic kind.We were reminded last year in celebrating the 50th anniversary of the 1963 March on Washington, people who put their beliefs into action, who have the courage and strength to persevere, do make a difference over time.  Such are the lessons of history made by folks who've lived and still live among us.  Such will be the lesson of the Wisconsin Uprising, and such will be the path we take as a nation and a world if we simply keep building on all we've done, and resolving to creatively keep doing it.This is the kind of multi-faceted storytelling I'm taking on with this book, based on my strengths as an interviewer skilled in the art of giving people a comfortable space in which to tell their own stories, and the insights that have come with several decades of my own activism.  It bears repeating:  in these times, we need and deserve to be inspired by the words and deeds of others.  It's times like these when it's now more important than ever for people of conscience and courage to reach out to each other as a means of finding new and innovative ways to make our voices heard.  That's what this book is all about--giving some ordinary yet ultimately extraordinary people a forum in which they can tell their own life stories.  As you can see by my bio, that's long been a focus of my own work. 

As you'll see from some of the examples of people who'll I'll be writing about below (a list that's by no means complete, and is growing every day), there are a lot of largely untold stories to tell, that I hope will inspire folks to make a difference themselves.However, I can't do it without your help.Please consider a donation of $5, $10, $25 or more.  (Larger donations will also reserve you a copy of the book.)  Please scroll down to the bottom of this page for an easy way to donate via credit card or paypal.I'd also appreciate your help in getting out the word by sharing this page with your friends in the social media.With your help, these efforts will form the foundation for a much larger and sustainable multimedia public education campaign--reminding folks of all that they can do, working individually and in supportive community--for many years to come....  Please consider using sending a donation today via the link at the top of the page, where you can contribute via credit card or paypal.  Working together, we can make a difference!Pictured just outside our community radio studio with my longtime friend and colleague, Charlie Daniel, recipient of both the city of Madison's ML King Award, and its James C. Wright Human Rights Award.  Like many of those whose stories will be featured in my book, her activism has spanned multiple issues, including civil rights, LGBT rights, and culturally competent health strategies for communities of color.  In particular, her outspoken leadership in creating support for LGBT youth of color has had a powerful effect in our community.  Ten years ago, I shared this memorable radio conversation with Charlie (edited down to five minutes), reflective of her belief in young people, and the affinity and passion she feels for them.  

The arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends toward justice.  
-- Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.


Immediately below are three representative examples of some of the individuals who will be featured in the book, folks who've been of all generations, and from a diversity of backgrounds and cultures, working on issues of racial and economic justice, LGBT rights, women's rights, disability rights, the environment, and much, much more. Embracing, Art, Heart, and Activism: Giving Voice to Our YouthWhen Sol Kelley-Jones was 10-years-old back in 1997, she was among the first children of lesbian and gay parents in Madison, Wisconsin's schools.  It wasn't always easy.  She was taunted by some, and also physically harassed, including being pushed down the stairs at her school. But she didn't retreat into a corner.  In experiencing the pain that came with those experiences of rejection and harassment, she reasoned that it came out of a basic lack of understanding.  And, in fourth and fifth grade, she paved the way for others by designing a curriculum that showcased LGBT role models and other positive messages about our families, and she testified at legislative hearings and other public settings, sharing her family's story, and making headlines statewide and beyond.  At age 12, she spoke before a half million people on the Mall in Washington, and began to receive attention in the national media, and awards from national social justice groups.  At 13, Sol and gay community leader Callen Harty co-founded Proud Theater, an award-winning multi-cultural youth theater company, featuring original works based on its young members' lives, still going strong today.  Over the years, her activism broadened and evolved to include issues of basic civil liberties alongside civil rights, as she helped lead high school students citywide to protest government excesses in the face of 9/11, and her work has always included a strong awareness of the need to support and empower young people of color.   Today, at age 27, her activism encompasses the full spectrum of social justice issues, resonant with a personal mission of finding ways to link "art, heart, and activism."  Her studies at Hampshire College took her to internships in the West Bank and along the US-Mexican border, and upon her return, she produced a powerful play, "The birds that are your hands: how to start a fire under siege" about the experiences of young people living life in the shadow of a wall.  While at Hampshire, she pioneered ways to apply dramatic techniques in ways that healed and informed people on the path to social justice.  Her work has since taken her all over the US, to the Middle East and recently to East Africa, where she therapeutically infuses art and drama in powerful ways that lift up young people and others facing trauma and prejudice. Her multi-faceted work continues at Proud Theater and multiple other venues, launching young people down the road to the realization of their greatest dreams.  Sol was recently honored on a CNN Headline News feature on Everyday Heroes.While Sol's early story was told more than a decade ago in six books, in newspaper venues ranging from the Chicago Tribune to the Los Angeles Times, in People Magazine, on public radio, and virtually every major television network, the totality of her recent story, and how her early history has influenced her activism as an adult, has never been told in one place before.  As someone who has been "Uncle John" to Sol for all of her life, she's trusting me to tell that story now.A Compassionate Vision for a More Sustainable World


Soon after Gene and Linda Farley had been married and both had become doctors in the 1950s, they moved with their young family from upstate New York to the Navajo Nation, where they helped bring medical care to thousands. They took what they learned, and, upon their return to New York, Gene took steps that led to the founding of the discipline of "family medicine," a holistic medical approach that brings in family and community as partners on the path to healing now practiced by over 100,000 doctors worldwide.  In 1963, they took the life-changing step of attending the March on Washington, reaffirming a lifelong commitment to racial and economic justice.  Their love for one another was inseparable from their love of the Earth and all of its inhabitants, and in recent years, they founded the Farley Center for Peace, Justice and Sustainability as a means of promoting good health, sustainable and health food practices, and a spirit of stewardship toward the Earth.  Linda left us four years ago and Gene in early November, and hundreds of folks came together recently at the celebration of Gene's life to mark the difference they'd made in our lives.  Click here for a link to an essay I wrote about Gene in the Madison Times, and click here for a link to a special radio show tribute I produced honoring Gene and Linda back in November.Teaching Younger Generations Why Voting Rights Matter
While she may have grown up knowing and learning from Dr. King, for whom she has great respect, Joanne Bland also knows that it was ordinary children and women like herself who formed the foundation of the black civil rights movement.  When she was was 11, she and her teenage sister experienced firsthand the carnage of Bloody Sunday, in the context of the 1965 Selma to Montgomery March for voting rights.  At that young age, she'd already been arrested 13 times for civil disobedience.  Initially facing down violent Alabama troupers by standing their ground with non-violence, she and her 14-year-old sister found themselves retreating to a nearby car amidst the bloody aftermath of the day's events. As they both cried tears of anguish, she felt a dampness coming down from her 14-year-old sister's brow, and realized that it was not her sister's tears, but her blood.  The incident shook a nation who saw it all play out on the national news.  
Dr. King came to town a short time later, joined by thousands of allies of all colors and creeds from around the US, a court order was obtained, and soon Joanne and her sister found themselves crossing the Edmund Pettus Bridge on the road to Montgomery, in a march that would lead a few months later to President Johnson's signing of the 1965 Voting Rights Act.  In 1992, she co-founded Selma's grasssroots National Voting Rights Museum to chronicle the role of ordinary people in that movement, and a few years later, she began yearly treks to Wisconsin to teach our young people about this important history. In turn, dozens of these Wisconsin young people have followed Joanne down South, where they were a vital force in building her museum.  




I first met Joanne on a trip to Selma in August 2006 with my friend, the
 Rev. Darrell Richey (at left in back row in photo), where we assisted with oral history projects and 
where I broadcast a live three hour version of my show from her museum.  There, in addition to Joanne, we met other Selma veterans, like Lawrence and Dorothea Huggins, who'd been teachers at the time of the March. In recent months, Lawrence had developed the only color footage of the March from film canisters that had been in storage for 40 years, which he proudly showed to us. After meeting Joanne, I was hooked, and I became part of the long history of Wisconsinites called to assist her in her important work, and had the privilege of being with her in Selma, and then Madison, as we viewed together first the nomination,then the inauguration, of this country's first African-American president.  I learned quickly, that dozens of young people have had their lives changed in knowing Ms. Bland, as we documented on my radio show in a tribute to the inspiring influence she's had on them.
Today, in this era of renewed race-based voter suppression and a recent Supreme Court decision that gutted the Voting Rights Act, Joanne's fight continues. US Senator Tammy Baldwin counts her visit to Joanne's museum in the company of Georgia US Rep. John Lewis eight years ago as one of the most inspiring such visits in her life.  Joanne followed and supported developments at the WI Capitol closely, and then US Rep. Baldwin also noted this resonance of movements in a speech at the Capitol delivered on the 44th anniversary of the Selma March.  Both of their stories are told in this video I produced in March of 2011, enitled Historic Resonances Between Madison and Selma, juxtaposing the powerful story-telling of two women who have both been civil rights pioneers.
Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world. Indeed, it is the only thing that ever has.

Margaret Mead

Here are some other folks whose stories I'll be previewing for you, in days to come in the Voices of Conscience and Courage blog:

Inspiring Others on the Path to Peace and Justice
  Former State Rep. Midge Miller is a political folk hero in her home state of Wisconsin, but the national role she played as a feminist leader and peace advocate may be less well-known.  As I learned on a special memorial edition of my radio show, as an advocate for women's rights, she was a contemporary of Friedan, Steinem, and Abzug, and her Madison colleague, NOW co-founder, Kathryn Clarenbach.  As an advocate for peace, she convinced her good friend, Minnesota Senator Eugene McCarthy, to run for president in 1968 as a means of advancing a peaceful solution in Vietnam. The candidacy that she spearheaded is widely seen as the development that caused President Lyndon Johnson not to run for another term.  
Throughout a distinguished career in the state legislature alongside colleagues like Mary Lou Munts and later Rebecca Young, she helped revitalize the WI Democratic party as a force for social justice.  In later years, her work with the Madison Institute, the WI Network for Peace and Justice, and in other realms formed the foundation for a lasting legacy.  Shortly before she passed away in 2009 after a courageous fight with cancer, her daughter-in-law recorded almost a dozen hours of videotaped interviews with her that have not yet been shared with the public.  Midge's son Mark (whose work is described below) has given me permission to use these interviews as a basis for a chapter in my book, and this will be the catalyst for efforts to share the tapes themselves more widely.  Eventually, we'd like to expand this project to include the stories of other politically active women who left their mark on Madison and the nation.  Again, your generous support will help to make this happen!

Young Photographer's Amazing Work Inspires 
Awareness and Action
  While 22-year-old Jenna Pope's activism is evocative of the powerful politicization of young women and men that occurred in the wake of the 2011 and 2012 protest at the Wisconsin Capitol, her motivation for becoming involved in rooted in the legacy of two earlier generations.  She first decided to march, and then live in the US Capitol, out of her love and respect for her mother, a lifelong teacher in her hometown of Edgerton.  Very quickly, her burgeoning talents as a photographer took wing, and her photos became some of the most personally compelling and evocative of the Capitol protests. She was a frequent guest on my radio show, as documented in this special video edition here. Her mother was immensely proud of her work, and saw it expand to Jenna's award-winning coverage of Occupy Wall Street and other protest movements worldwide. Two years ago, Jenna experienced the loss of both her mother and her beloved grandmother in the space of a few short weeks.  With the support of her father and other family members, she has transformed her grief into a new resolve to use her photographs and dispatches as a means of educating people about the nature of social justice protests around the world, including trips this past summer to Turkey's Taksim Square.  
This fall, she launched a crowdfunding project on Indiegogo, raising almost $20,000 for her new book "Jenna Pope: An Activist Armed with a Camera," due out later this month.  See JennaPope.com .  Both Jenna and I are blessed with hundreds and hundreds of folks who follow our work on Facebook and elsewhere, as activist-journalists.  Jenna's success is part of what encouraged me to think outside of the box and find a way to make this book project self-sustaining.  Please believe me in me, too, and consider making a contribution!
A Cultural Translator Paving the Way for Latino LGBT People
  Since moving to Madison from his native Ecuador in 2002, Diego Campoverde-Cisneros has made a major mark on our community as both a broadcaster at La Movida, Madison's Spanish-language radio station, and in his work in the larger community.  A leader in efforts to create community for LGBT people of color, he is a co-founder of Alianza Latina, an LGBT support group.  In 2013, he received the "Alix Olson Social Justice Award," named after a highly-respected longtime openly lesbian Madison police detective, presented by STAJOH, the coalition she co-founded to counter hate crimes and hate groups locally. As Alix herself noted, it was a fitting honor for this young man who has done so much to build bridges and increase understandings in our community.

There is No Normal:  Honoring Cognitive Diversity   Unlike some of the other people who's stories I'll be telling, Jonathan Mooney is not from Wisconsin, although he has spent extensive time as a consultant working with the University of Wisconsin-Madison's School of Education.  More than almost anyone else I've had the privilege of interviewing over the years, my conversations with Jonathan moved me in ways that continue to give me almost daily personal insights, and further inform my world view.  He's the author of "The Short Bus: A Journal Beyond Normal."Saddled with the labels "ADHD" and "dyslexia" at an early age, Jonathan at 13 was a special ed student who still couldn't read.  And yet, less than a decade later, he received an English Lit degree from  prestigious Brown University, graduating with honors.  His journey might have stopped there, self-defined as how he had overcome all of the shortcomings and failures of his younger self.  But instead, a few years later, Jonathan embarked on an incredible odyssey of discovery--traveling cross-country, in a short bus, no less--as a means of meeting other young people coping with the challenges and unfair judgements that come with labels connected with cognitive and emotional disability, not unlike his 13-year-old younger self.  Expecting at first to be in a position to provide these young people with comfort and insights, instead, he discovered that it was these young people who had so much to teach him.  Soon he learned that the key to his own self-realization was not to reject his younger self, but to embrace who he was at the core of his being.His book has particular resonance with young people who have been labeled as developmentally disabled or extremely gifted, who just don't fit into the "one-size-fits-all" approach adopted by many schools, but it also has lessons for us all.  Among the memorable truths Jonathan imparts is that it's usually "dysteachia," not dyslexia, that lies at the root of young person's challenges.  He is an advocate for our society's embrace of the concept of "cognitive diversity," with broad implications for its importance as a new way of viewing individual rights, and weighing the horrible consequences when we attempt to establish arbitrary standards for what constitutes "normal."  A definition of disability can often be reframed and reconsidered as part of the richness of the diversity of human experience, with worth beyond measure.  Aside from its applications in terms of creativity, it also has more practical applications.  For example, a recent study revealed that more than 60 percent of the student body of M.I.T.  could be considered to be "learning disabled," by testing standards that ignore the value of individual difference.Jonathan has become an inspirational speaker and educational consultant who has touched thousands of lives through his work.  Never one to take himself too seriously, his narratives contain a playful and highly irreverent element that's ultimately endearing. His admonition to young people to join him on a revolution against all that is normal, is actually represents quite a serious quest.  Based today out of Santa Monica, California, his latest social venture is a social project called "Streetcraft LA," which works with at risk youth, street hustlers, tag bangers, supporting them in becoming creative economy volunteers.
Have You Been to Jail for Justice:  Taking a Stand   Damon Terrell, president of the Autonomous Solidarity Organization, was an active participant in the Wisconsin Protests.  Singled out and brutally arrested in August 2013 by the Capitol police while participating in the Solidarity Singalong, the police's excesses were captured on videotape.  He endured jail and the threat of a felony prosecution for the cause he believed in.  Still he had to ask himself:  why did the police choose to single him out?Standing on Principle Even in a Time of Fear
       While serving on the Madison School Board in the days immediately following 9/11, Bill Keys refused to bend to the will of the mob in refusing to force students to say the Pledge of Allegiance.  It's one of many stands of conscience he and his wife Linda have taken over the years for countless causes, including mental health consumer rights, racial and economic justice, and LGBT rights.  I met Bill and Linda as they did tireless service on a powerful and broad coalition that came together to persuade the local United Way to discontinue funding the Boy Scouts as along as they continued to discriminate against gay Scouts and gay Scout leaders.  Here he stands in front of a Hmong wall hanging at a benefit for Kasjiab House, a group founded to alleviate the trauma facing Hmong elders as a resonant result of the Vietnam War.
A History-Making Nurse Who Educates and Spreads UnderstandingsBarbara Nichols's history-making firsts include being the first African-American woman to serve as the head of the National Nurse's Association, and the first African-American woman to serve as a member of the governor's cabinet.  In recent years, she's traveled the world recruiting international healthcare workers for needed positions in the US.  As a result, she has a remarkable range of insights about the professional and multi-culturally competent management of organizations in the private, public and nonprofit sectors, particularly in the area of healthcare. While officially retired, she's a speaker in much demand at colleges and universities across the country, who have given her almost a dozen honorary degrees over the years.  She currently serves as the president of the Dane County chapter of the UN Association-USA.
Living Out the Cause of PeaceJoseph and Joann Elder are community treasures, with a long history of action on behalf of the creation of a peace-filled world, resonant with their Quaker faith.  In addition to distinguished service for sixty years as a UW Sociology and South Asian faculty member, he has mediated disputes in venues like Vietnam and Afghanistan.  She has advised countless young people as the longtime advisor for the Sociology Department, and helped to found the local chapter of PFLAG (Parents, Family and Friends of LGBT people).  Together they serve on countless community boards and UW committees.  Look for my article in an upcoming dispatch in the Voices of Conscience and Courage blog. 
Faith in Action Means Being Willing to Put It All on the Line   Gene Matthews is a longtime friend of my father, who met him at the airport in Seoul, South Korea 60 years ago as they both embarked on a short term Methodist missions program.  In recent years, he's also become one of my best friends, and favorite people.  While he had met me as an infant, I next saw Gene almost fifty years later, just following my father's death in June 2010, and he gave me countless insights into my father's path as a young man.  Gene married his wife Insook and remained in South Korea until retirement, joining a group of missionaries of diverse faiths in standing up to brutally oppressive military regimes, risking death, imprisonment and deportation.  A culmination of this work was their support of eight men who'd been wrongly accused of treason, and then summarily executed.  They were allied with human rights advocate Kim Dae Jung--himself the near victim of several assassination attempts--who eventually became president of South Korea in 1997.  Gene and George Ogle (another missionary friend of my dad's, who earned both his master's and doctoral degrees at the University of Wisconsin) were invited to to the new president's inaugural, and then were given one of South Korea's highest honors for their courageous human rights work.  All of this is chronicled in a remarkable book called "More Than Witnesses," for which I produced a special event at the October 2010 Wisconsin Book Festival.  See this blog I created, that chronicles the event, the story behind it, and the media associated with it.  
Promoting Social Justice and CommunityGladis Benavides (left) is a close friend and colleague, who has become like family to me.  Born in Brazil, and raised in Peru on a ranch located just a short hike from Macchu Picchu, her ancestors included a Peruvian president, and her father was a former mayor of Lima.  As a teen she attended the Sorbonne, briefly lived in Morocco, and then at 19, she moved to Madison.  Soon becoming a single mother of two, her life circumstances were considerably different than those she'd grown up with, but she loved her new home and her new friends, and was determined to make life in Madison work.  Over many years, she honed her skills as a tireless advocate--becoming a highly-respected state and municipal employee in the field of equal opportunity, and then an accomplished workplace trainer and consultant--helping organizations to become culturally competent, how to understand and observe equal opportunity laws, and how to avoid workplace conflict. She is a respected truthspeaker on matters of racial and economic justice, and it's been my privilege to work closely with her in recent years.  Few people I know epitomize as she does the notion of being a voice of conscience and courage.Barbara McKinney (right) moved to Madison from St. Louis to take care of her beloved son Mike, who died eight years ago.  Mike McKinney was a TV anchor universally respected both for his integrity as a journalist and his tireless community service, in particular his work on behalf of the Second Harvest Food Bank, and AIDS Network.  Barbara elected to stay in Madison, and she soon became the associate director of the Madison Urban Ministry.  Though known at first as "Mike's mom," Barbara quickly became a respected leader in her own right in the area of restorative justice, and for her tireless work on behalf of numerous community boards.    
San Franciscan's Storytelling and Activism Knows No Bounds Joanie Juster lives in San Francisco, but is considered by many to be an honorary Wisconsinite.  Less than a week after the onset of protests at the Wisconsin Capitol, she'd purchased a one way ticket to Madison and was living amidst the diverse group of citizens who occupied the Capitol.  She first became familiar with Wisconsin while doing research for an award-winning documentary film entitled "Alaska Far and Away," which airs periodically on PBS stations nationwide.  The film chronicles the migration of Upper Midwesterners during the Great Depression to the Matanuska Valley of Alaska, seeking a better life.  Joanie has a long history of working on behalf of social justice, and is an esteemed ally of the Bay Area's LGBT community.  Her activism includes being an early supporter of the NAMES Project Quilt, where she worked closely with her good friend Cleve Jones (founder of the Quilt, and an early associate of Harvey Milk.)  During a recent display of the Quilt on the National Mall in DC, Joanie was interviewed by Smithsonian Institution researchers about its early history.  Her current project is a film on the life of Sister Simone Campbell.  Joanie has returned to Wisconsin several times in recent years.  While disappointed in the outcome of the June 2012 recall election, she believes that the citizens who came together in protest will eventually prevail.  And she'll be right there, standing beside us.


Love Conquers All

Mark Miller and Jo Oyama-Miller have long worked together as a team on behalf of social justice.  (Mark is the son of Midge Miller, mentioned above, and Jo is a second generation Japanese-American whose family was sent to internment camps in World War II.)  Married in 1968 just following the Supreme Court's "Loving v. Virginia" case, which struck down the prohibition in many southern states against interracial marriage, they first lived in Selma, where Mark was stationed as an Air Force pilot.  In a memorable 2006 interview on my radio show, Mark explained how that personal experience had made him realize that "two people who love each other should never be denied the right of marriage."  
As a leader in the State Senate, Mark was one of 14 Democratic senators to leave the state as a means of delaying passage of draconian bills without process by their GOP counterparts.  Jo has a long history of community service, including her tenure at the Community Action Coalition. They, too, have long been voices of conscience and courage in Madison.




The Compassionate Critic
                  

In March of 2006, I interviewed Roger Ebert, in the context of the Wisconsin Film Festival.  it was one of the last interviews he would conduct before losing his voice during cancer surgery a short time later.  Despite this, the highly-principled Ebert found other ways to express himself, and continued to be a prolific writer until his death last year.  On this occasion, we had a spirited discussion about the history of the depiction of LGBT community leaders in film.  Our conversation was resonant with his overall belief, Infused throughout Ebert's film criticism, that this powerful medium can overcome its shortcomings, and be a powerful force for social change.   Roger Ebert is one of a handful of "famous" people I'll be covering in my book.  However, I strongly believe that he belongs here as someone who understood the responsibility that comes with notoriety, and who remained an accessible and compassionate advocate for all human beings throughout his lifetime.


Transforming A LIfe of Challenge into the Promise of a Better Life for OthersKaren Ott Avery, who passed away unexpectedly in late October of last year at the age of 51, was one of my dearest friends.  She'd faced an unimaginably difficult childhood,  and she was forced to live on her own at age 12. In becoming a single mom at age 16, she resolved that her own children would have a better life, and she delivered on that promise.  "Transformative" is a word that describes her well, as someone who took difficult and sometimes painful life lessons and made them into something life-giving and empowering of others facing resonant struggles.  When I first got to know her, she was in her mid-20s, a mature and wise young woman, who was an effective leader of our newly-formed Fair Housing Council (where she was director, and I was board president).  The friendship grew strong over the years.  She was someone whose enthusiasm was infectious, whose sense of humor was generously applied, and who knew how to bring out the best in everyone she was around.  She worked tirelessly for racial justice at both our council and Milwaukee Fair Housing.  In 1998, she became the associate director of the large Milwaukee disability rights agency, Independence First.  She spoke out often about her own experiences with emotional disability, and helped found the Grassroots Empowerment Project, an agency that provides a framework of support for mental health consumers statewide. Karen never wanted to be the center of attention in the public eye, but nonetheless, she inspired others through her tireless and facilitative leadership. She was a great friend, as hundreds of folks affirmed at her memorial service through countless stories of how she'd made a difference in our lives.  Karen's last year of life was extremely rough for her, as resonant traumas from her childhood and youth came back to haunt her, and her physical health began deterioriating.  She is at peace now, and her legacy lives on in the lives of her beloved family, and the countless friends whose lives she's touched.It's in Karen's memory that I dedicate this book.
****
There are a variety of premia available at different levels of giving listed in the boxes at right.  Any amount will appreciated, and will be a further catalyst for future support by others!  (That's the nature of a site like indiegogo.)  
Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Please help me to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
Toward that end, be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools on this site.

If you have questions, please drop me a note at John.L.Quinlan at gmail dot com, and thanks in advance for your support of this important project, shining a light on folks whose devotion to social justice is making a difference in this world each and every day.*********


 And so, in conclusion, we return to that important question of what one person can do, and how we find the courage to do it.The African American science fiction writer Octavia Butler, writing about her history-making friend Shirley Chisholm, wrote: "The idea is that people are fearless, and that's why they're taking action.  I think that it's more important to realize that they're terrified, and they're still taking action, that they know exactly what they're risking, and they still risk it."Below:  Callen Harty had a deep-seated fear of singing in public.  But early in 2011, he began a tradition of journeying to the cavernous Rotunda of the WI State Capitol, and proudly belting out a powerful solo rendition of "We Shall Overcome." It was an ongoing means of supporting the pro-workers' rights, pro-education, pro-democracy movement taking place there.  He was afraid, but he simply put one foot in front of the other and made it happen.  Callen's is among dozens of stories of people working for social change that will be told in my new book, "Voices of Conscience and Courage."Please considering supporting this effort in any way you can, through your financial contribution, or by helping spread the word.   Thanks!

story:
Us:

If there's anything the 5 of us have in common, it's a love for travel and being a part of something that will make the world a better place. Megan, Ryan and Amanda met in the Ecuadorian Amazon jungle where we taught various subjects at a rural boarding high school. Matt volunteered with an NGO in Ethiopia which sought to encourage farmers to invest in crop-saving irrigation technology, and Chelsea is soon to embark on a journey to Israel where she will enter a Master's program in Non-Profit Management.

We don't want to stop traveling, and we still want to effect positive change in the world! So we're asking for your help to reach our goal to summit Mt. Kilimanjaro this summer to raise money to provide sight-saving surgeries for children in Guatemala, Nicaragua and Haiti. Here's how it works:

The Organization: Vision for the Poor

So, we have to admit, this wasn't all our own idea! We're climbing with a non-profit organization called Vision for the Poor. The organization has established a successful model for developing eye clinics that is sustainable and places emphasis on empowering local economies and health care systems. Rather than sending Western eye doctors to a developing community to provide eye care for a short 2-week mission trip, Vision for the Poor works with local eye doctors and their staff with the goal that the eye clinic will be self-sustaining within 3 years of opening its doors. This method has proven more cost effective and successful in providing longer-term care for local people.

Our goal:

This crowd-funding campaign is just part of our fundraising strategy. We have set our crowd-funding goal at $10,000 to supplement our larger goal of $50,000, and your contribution helps us to reach that goal as a group. If we reach this mark, this amount will provide 250 sight-restoring eye surgeries for children who visit the clinics. Children under the age of 14 receive free care at the clinics as a result of the contributions of people like you who support climbers like us.

The Impact:

Imagine this: $200 dollars will allow another person to SEE. That's right, your contribution of two-hundred dollars will provide sight to another person who would otherwise live their life in darkness. Sight is more than just the ability to see the world, it's also a ticket into a profitable job, the ability to live independently and raise a family, and the option and opportunity to move oneself out of a state of poverty.

Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone can give $200, but we are asking for your support in any way you feel comfortable. Here is what your contribution can provide:

  1. 1/2 penny per foot    = $97         = 1/2 sight-restoring surgery
  2. 1 penny per foot       = $194       = 1 surgery
  3. 2 cents per foot         = $388       = 2 surgeries
  4. 5 cents per foot         = $970       = 5 surgeries
  5. 10 cents per foot       = $1,940    = 10 surgeries
  6. 25 cents per foot       = $4,850    = 25 surgeries
  7. $1.00 per foot            = $19,400  = anesthesia equipment at a new Vision for the Poor eye clinic

story:
Story of My Book 

Las locas (the madwomen) is a book about the effects that the Dirty War in Argentina has had and continues to have on families, even today in 2020.

My name is Kaleigh Garraffa and I am the author of Las locas (the madwomen). I wrote this book because I was inspired from a Latin American film class I took my sophomore year of college. We delved into the tragic story about how thousands of women and children went missing from being harmed or killed by the dictators in the 1970’s, causing many newborns and young kids to be left without parents.


The terrifying reality that these tragic crimes and murders were committed  by government officials struck a chord of both inspiration and horror. How are people capable of such wicked acts? Are human beings really all inherently good? After learning about the Dirty War, a spark ignited in me: I knew this would be the background of my first mystery book.

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover the tragedy of the Dirty War’s effect on individuals and families. I want you to see this book as an opportunity to engage with themes such as strong, powerful women, the power of family, and the dark, terrifying scope of humanity found in the mystery genre. I hope Las Locas  helps you escape from the mundanities of everyday reality, and learn alongside the characters Catalina, Rosa, and Magdalena about the importance of relationships, spirituality, and creative outlets such as art, tarot reading, cooking, or wine connoisseurship.

Las locas (the madwomen) takes place in Buenos Aires, Argentina, and follows the stories and perspectives of Catalina: a middle aged artist with dead parents and insecurities that she hides behind using a paint brush, Rosa: an elderly psychic who has suffered and survived grief far too many times, and Magdalena: a cold, materialistic mother living with unthinkable guilt, as well as an affinity for expensive wine and showing off to others.

After Catalina’s parents’ death, her world gets turned upside down as she digs into their past. Was she really their daughter? What secrets were they hiding? Were they really so dark that they were willing to die for them? Rosa has searched for her stolen grand-daughter for over 30 years and is getting closer and closer to finding her, thanks to her psychic abilities and internet savvy daughter. Magdalena’s world differs from both Catalina’s and Rosa’s. Her sheltered and white porcelain home screams perfection and materialism, but her hidden regrets and yearning for more in life scream sorrow and remorse. Through the merge of these three worlds, heartbreak, love, loss, joy, guilt, bittersweet reunions and goodbyes echo through the lives of the characters.

You will love this book if you are a mystery fan, are interested in Tarot reading and other divination tools that connect us to the spiritual world, or want to learn more about a crucial moment in Argentinian history.

Las locas (the madwomen) speaks to the Argentinian and other Latin American communities and feminists who want to grapple with Argentinian history and women empowerment in a new way.

Ultimately, I hope that Las locas (the madwomen) inspires reflection and fruitful dialogue, pressing into engaging questions like:

  • How far would I be willing to achieve my deepest desires?
  • How do our family values manifest themselves in our relationships?
  • Are human beings really capable of such evil?
I really look forward to exploring these questions and beyond with my readers. Coming together and discussing the Dirty War, women empowerment, and family values will change us all for the better.
 

What I Need & What You'll Get

This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:

  • The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in April, 2021.
  • The Cover Design of my book. (The mockups you see currently are a placeholder!)
  • The Layout Design for the interior of my book (physical copy, ebook formats).
  • The Copyediting for my book to polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication.
  • The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book when I ultimately publish this Spring.
When I pre-sell 120 copies of my book, I will publish a paperback and ebook. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish a hardcover edition. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover and an audiobook.

I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:

You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish and a handwritten thank-you note.

  • Your name will appear in the Acknowledgments section of my book (“with Special Thanks to”).
  • You will receive early access to the Introduction and some excerpts from my book, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback.
  • You will have the opportunity to be involved in selecting my cover and title.
  • You will be invited to join my Author Community and get behind-the-scenes sneak peeks into the publishing process.

And much more!

 

About the Author


Kaleigh Garraffa is a senior at Marist College double majoring in Communications and Spanish, with a minor in Creative Writing. She works as an on-campus tutor and participates in various extracurricular positions, such as writing for the Marist chapter of the national magazine, “Hercampus” and working as the social media chair for Marist’s art club, Redink.

It has always been a dream of Kaleigh’s to write a book, especially in the mystery genre. As someone who is passionate about Latin American culture and history, once she learned about the Dirty War, educating others on the effects that the tragic event had/has on families has become very important to her.

Outside of writing and her studies, Kaleigh loves singing and listening to music (her favorite band is One Direction), is an animal rights activist, and loves spending time with her family, friends, and three dogs. She is extremely passionate about Tarot reading, goat cheese, and red wine.

For more information, you can connect with Kaleigh Garraffa at kaleighmgarraffa@yahoo.com and through her Instagram, @kaleighauthor.
 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please share my pre-sale campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family and network. Please use #[Laslocas] and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press, so we can help amplify your efforts.

You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page.

Please share my book with 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it via text or direct message on social media.

Thank you so much for of all of your love and support!

Thanks again,
Kaleigh Garraffa

Through the merge of these three worlds, heartbreak, love, loss, joy, guilt, bittersweet reunions and goodbyes echo through the lives of the characters.
You will love this book if you are a mystery fan, are interested in Tarot reading and other divination tools that connect us to the spiritual world, or want to learn more about a crucial moment in Argentinian history.Las locas (the madwomen) speaks to the Argentinian and other Latin American communities and feminists who want to grapple with Argentinian history and women empowerment in a new way.Ultimately, I hope that Las locas (the madwomen) inspires reflection and fruitful dialogue, pressing into engaging questions like:


How far would I be willing to achieve my deepest desires?
How do our family values manifest themselves in our relationships?
Are human beings really capable of such evil?
I really look forward to exploring these questions and beyond with my readers. Coming together and discussing the Dirty War, women empowerment, and family values will change us all for the better. What I Need & What You'll Get

story:
Story of My Book

American Football: The Future of Soccer in the United States.

My name is Aidan Chapman and I am the author of American Football: The Future of Soccer in the United States. I wrote this book because Soccer has been one of the only aspects of my life that has kept me consistently motivated. I love the sport as a fan and as an ex-player. Now it is time for me to grow affection for the sport as a writer as well. 

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will begin to understand why American Soccer has failed thus far, and how it will be revived. In this book, I hope to instill the same sort of passion and excitement that I have for Soccer in you. And then ultimately I want you to see this book as a tool to help you see into the way I perceive the world and learn about soccer from a completely new lens.

In this book, you'll learn about Soccer and its affiliation within the United States:

How teams like Chattanooga Football Club have arranged their value to mimic European Sports

How the Global Soccer Community operates

How the United States can and should adjust their system in order to cohere with the wider footballing world

You will love this book if you are interested in Soccer and how sports are effected by the world around them.
American Football: The Future of Soccer in the United States is a non-fiction book that speaks to Soccer Fans and Proponents of American Advancement who are looking at Soccer and How the United States work together for the first time.

The Book - American Football: The Future of Soccer in the United States


The book is written in 5 Parts....

In part 1, you will learn about the history of global soccer specifically within the United States and in Great Britain as well on the continent of Europe as a whole.

Part 2 contains my personal story with American soccer, which is one of the most unique stories in the entire book.

Part 3 is all about what American soccer at a larger scale is like. The part includes stories ranging from players like Christian Pulisic and Carlos Tevez, to how the pay-to-play system has been set up to work.

Part 4 is centered around the stories of clubs and people who have used the less traveled path when it comes to American Soccer. They have set up their teams and clubs to run in way that might seem contrary to Major League Soccer or other popular American sports leagues. It includes exclusive interviews with both Sheldon Grizzle from Chattanooga Football Club and Dennis Crowley from Stockade.

In Part 5, I will disclose what I have discerned as one of the best answers to combating the stagnation of American soccer talent and improving the game as a whole. 

What I Need & What You'll Get


This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:
 

The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in July 2020

The Cover Design of my Book - the mockups you see currently are a placeholder!

The Layout Design for the interior of my book (Physical Copy, Ebook Formats)

The Copyediting for My Book - to help polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication

The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish this summer

In light of current events, I have made an update on the campaign. Due to the COVID-19 Pandemic, All additional proceeds will be put forth for COVID-19 relief. After reaching my 4,000 dollar goal, everything will go to Direct Relief. For more information on Direct Relief please check out their website here: https://www.directrelief.org/emergency/coronavi...

I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:
You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish

A Personal, handwritten thank you note for pre-ordering my book

Your Name will appear in a Special, Acknowledgements Section of my book (“with Special Thanks to”)

Early access to the Introduction of my Book and my entire manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback

The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover

I will do a book topic/workshop seminar where I will share the experiences of writing my book

And more...

About the Author

Aidan Chapman is a High School Student in Omaha Nebraska at Creighton Prep. He currently works as an intern at Chapman & Company where he has worked for several months. He has written and published countless articles for Silicon Prairie News and has also been involved in entrepreneurial builder challenges across the state where he has worked with representatives from Gallup and other large area businesses and associations.

I am super passionate about Soccer. I love the sport as a fan and as a writer. I loved the sport as a player as well when I was involved. For this reason, I feel as though it is only natural for me to continue to contribute to the sport from a broader stance than just as a fan and as a player. Writing about the game has broadened my understanding of the soccer community tremendously.

Many American Soccer fans, myself included, have been quite dissatisfied with the way the United States Men’s National Team has performed in the past, especially in failing to reach the 2018 World Cup. My Book addresses some of the shortcomings of the United States Soccer system and the future of the system and the sport in the country as a whole.

At the end of the day, I am just another American soccer fan. The only thing separating me from the person next me is a couple hundred pages.

For more information you can connect with Aidan at achap2021@gmail.com on Instagram @aidan_chapman2021, on Twitter @aidandchapman, and you can find my LinkedIn here.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please Share my Pre-sale Campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, SnapChat, and LinkedIn with your friends, family and network. Please use #NewAmericanFootball and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press so we can help amplify your efforts.

You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page

Please share my book to 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it. Please do this as a text message or Direct Message on social media.

Thank you so much of all of your love and support!

Thanks again,
Aidan

story:
"You had to be there" may be an overused phrase, but those who witnessed the court proceedings for the Oregon Standoff trials have just cause to use it. One of the strangest trials in federal court history. 26 defendants, many who choose to represent themselves inside of a courtroom that they do not believe is legitimate. All the while battling a  judicial system not allowed to judge them on their beliefs. All documented by a guy with no law or artistic experience. 

So take what you know about law, patriotism, art, and most importantly common sense, and toss it out the window. Bundy Court is now in session. 

The Bundy Court Sketch project

 Alt right, conspiracy theories, religious extremism, wacky Mormons, a good Sheriff and a bad Sheriff?, wacky Christian preppers, Sovereign Citizens movement, bumbling law enforcement, drama, hilarity, and the winning attorney gets tased.  What else could you want????

Unapologetically scratchy, misspelled cartoons...

The cartoons are satire while still helping document my account of the proceedings of this bizarrely complex case. Snacks not included. 

MORE INFO:

The Oregonian's feature on the Bundy Court Sketches by Maxine Bernstein  

http://www.oregonlive.com/oregon-standoff/2017/...

Cheri Roberts and her early day expose' on the Bundy Court Sketches.

https://challengingtherhetoric.wordpress.com/20...

 

The Book and perks (don't forget to select a perk)

"bundy et al" will run over 300 pages. 7" X 10" paperback with black and white illustrations. The Indiegogo backers will receive a first run "backer edition" that will have a section of extra photos and sketches in the back. All books are signed with extra original hand drawn sketches inside. 

Original Hand Drawn sketches! The extra unframed sketches will be originals, with one courtroom scene and another of a different Bundy trial related subjects. Available with the "Superbook" and "Prepper" packages.

Decal sets - 2 promotional decals 4" X 4" - with Superbook and Prepper packages

"The Migration" - Was the first book I did last year. A fictional story based on the Oregon and Bunkerville standoffs. Want to add it to you order? Grab the "Prepper Package."

 

WHEN WILL THIS CRAP SHIP?

October 2017

 

Today and the future ...

As of writing this, the book is about 3/4 done. However, as many of the trial followers know there is still a lot going on that I will no doubt try to cram in the book at the last minute. Still, I expect the roll out on this one to go much smoother than the first book "The Migration."

The first book was meant in part to be a fundraiser to cover some expenses to cover some of the Nevada trials that was supposed to start early 2017. Those trials were broken up into three, with the biggest trial postponed until this Fall and Winter. The first book sales ended up helping a lot with coverage for both of the Oregon trials, as well as some pre-funding for the NV trials. In turn, the can will get kicked again, and part of the money from this book will help with Nevada coverage. The more made the more coverage I can do.... but hey no pressure.

story:
The author, the book, and the tour

I'm the author of Train Shots: stories and Juventud, a novel, and have received numerous literary awards and fellowships. My writing has appeared in The Southern Review, Green Mountains Review, The Paris Review Daily, Kenyon Review Online, and elsewhere. Juventud won the 2015 IPPY Bronze Medal in Literary Fiction, was a finalist for Foreword Review’s Book of the Year, and a runner-up for the Eric Hoffer Award;Train Shots won the 2014 IPPY Gold Medal in Short Fiction. My third book, Perfect Conditions: stories, will be published in July, 2018, by Curbside Splendor (Chicago, USA). I'm excited to bring these stories to the widest possible audience this fall via invited appearances at esteemed book festivals and literary events, such as the Miami Book Fair International. Your contribution will enable me to offset travel expenses associated with presenting the book at key events.   

About the book: 

"Everyone here is both at home and lost: a deep sea fisherman discovers he
may not be allowed to return to shore; a newlywed couple embark on a
disastrous honeymoon; a niece and uncle debate the ethics of hunting after
a nuclear fallout; a surfer struggles between cross-continental commitments
and local attractions; and a single mother begins preparations for the end of
the world as we know it. From the unforgiving surf of Costa Rica to suburban
Florida, the stories in Perfect Conditions arise within worlds we know and
others that only resemble our own. Blakeslee’s characters often struggle to
find control in unrelenting circumstances, in places which are often anything
but welcoming."

Want to read an excerpt from the book? Check out:

"Jesus Surfs," published by the Atticus Review: https://atticusreview.org/jesus-surfs/

"The Perfect Pantry," published by Burrow Press at Fantastic Floridas: http://burrowpress.com/the-perfect-pantry-vanes...

In short, these are stories that capture the turbulent times we live in. Your contribution will directly impact getting the book to as many readers as possible -- as well as to judges and critics!

I'm asking for $2500 to offset travel expenses, based on the previous budget and funds raised during the Juventud book launch campaign via Indiegogo in 2015. I plan to present Perfect Conditions at the venues and festivals that garnered the greatest turnout for my previous books, including (but not limited to): the Toadstool bookshop in New Hampshire, Fall for the Book, Miami Book Fair International, and an Orlando-area launch party this fall. Your contributions will help make this possible.     

Those who donate over $150 may get in touch with me directly to receive a signed copy of either Train Shots, Juventud, or Perfect Conditions - your choice. For updates, please visit www.vanessablakeslee.com. And lastly, please share the campaign to help get the word out -- any and all contributions are greatly appreciated!

story:
Short Summary

I am Clarence Mason “Weaver” minister, author and motivational speaker. I wrote “Tribalism” to explain why the black community supports organizations and individuals who have proven to be working against our individual best interest? Why do we reject proven methods of self help and success? “Tribalism” addresses those questions in the form of a fictional novel. 

My first book “It’s ok to Leave the Plantation” was more of a history book with my life story. It discussed the historical record of success and failures. But “Tribalism” is a story, discovering why we, the descendants of slaves, are still acting like slaves decades after the practiced ended.

This is a story of a tough drug dealing 14-year-old child discovering who he really is when he finds himself 150 years back into slavery. It forces him to recognize the true freedoms he had and understands the struggles which were paid by others. 

This book will start the conversation, truth will bring the conversion. However, because of it's forbidden topic and anti-tribal chiefs views, we cannot publish it through normal means. This effort has to be guided by principles and protected with independence. This is why we need your help to publish and distribute it. 

Can you imagine what will happen in America if the black community gave something back to their spouses and family instead of the “community?” What would happen instead of not forgetting where we “came from”, we did not forget where we were “going?”

The truth will set you free, believing a lie will enslave you. Help us spread the truth. 

A Black Gang member robs a store and is shot in this mysterious field call The Pass. He wakes up to find himself 150 years back in history during slavery. He has been shot by slave hunters escaping the plantation. He remembers the future and realized how much he has lost. He is now a slave and helpless. He has no control and no hope. The lessons Jordan learns could lead him back to freedom.   

What We Need & What You Get

Have you ever known an abused woman? She will support the abuser, not the rescuer. She thinks supporting him will stop the beating and gain his love. The more he beats her the more support she has for him. If you call the police SHE will fight the police. If he leaves her she will find another just like him. The black community has suffered like an abused person. From slavery, Jim Crow, to the welfare system, we have been abused. But when any abused person gets enough, then watch out. We have had enough! The only way the abused person can really finally escape is to have a safe environment to rest and gather. “Tribalism” gives that abuse some light. It explains the brutality of the tribal leaders keeping the community under control. It is a powerful tool to start the self-healing process. 

However, like that abused woman, we will only seek help after we gets enough. This book is not for everyone, only those seeking help. Most will not buy the book, we have to give it to them. Help us provide a copy to the abused people.

I have self published 6 books and have sold thousands of copies. But this book cannot be sold through my normal marketing. It is marketed to a different client. I need to raise $10,000 to publish the first edition. I will donate hundreds of copies to key segments of the black community and follow up with a serious discussion of the issues. I offer no hope in changing the hearts and minds of every tribal member, but unless you send me, those looking to be free may never get the information.

We can change America, not black America, white America, poor or rich, but AMERICA. A place of no hyphenations, just Americans. But ONLY if you send a message.

The Impact

If the power to change is placed in the hands of the individual, change is much easier to accomplished. Like that abused woman, if she can control her destiny with information and support, it is much easier to leave the situation. 

From my radio program, public speaking and general books, I have had success in changing the directions and hearts of many people. However, after the conversation there is nothing to leave them with. There is no connection to other like-minded people. With your help we can close that gap.

I know this task will not be easy or without risk. But, the only way we will transform America is to face the obvious and challenge it. All of us cannot do this, I have been doing it for 30 years. All of us cannot deliver the message, I can, but only if you send me.

Other Ways You Can Help

We need this message to go viral. Spread the word, share this message, join our organization, participate in the debate. This nation is not growing weak. It is still strong, but only if we decide something must be done. Not everyone is called to the front lines but everyone is called to support. 

Use the Indiegogo share tool and lets make this a success.

This is your nation, your culture and your future and your project. No one is free unless ALL are free!

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Short Summary
I am Clarence Mason “Weaver” minister, author and motivational speaker. I wrote “Tribalism” to explain why the black community supports organizations and individuals who have proven to be working against our individual best interest? Why do we reject proven methods of self help and success? “Tribalism” addresses those questions in the form of a fictional novel. 
My first book “It’s ok to Leave the Plantation” was more of a history book with my life story. It discussed the historical record of success and failures. But “Tribalism” is a story, discovering why we, the descendants of slaves, are still acting like slaves decades after the practiced ended.
This is a story of a tough drug dealing 14-year-old child discovering who he really is when he finds himself 150 years back into slavery. It forces him to recognize the true freedoms he had and understands the struggles which were paid by others. 
This book will start the conversation, truth will bring the conversion. However, because of it's forbidden topic and anti-tribal chiefs views, we cannot publish it through normal means. This effort has to be guided by principles and protected with independence. This is why we need your help to publish and distribute it. 
Can you imagine what will happen in America if the black community gave something back to their spouses and family instead of the “community?” What would happen instead of not forgetting where we “came from”, we did not forget where we were “going?”
The truth will set you free, believing a lie will enslave you. Help us spread the truth. 
A Black Gang member robs a store and is shot in this mysterious field call The Pass. He wakes up to find himself 150 years back in history during slavery. He has been shot by slave hunters escaping the plantation. He remembers the future and realized how much he has lost. He is now a slave and helpless. He has no control and no hope. The lessons Jordan learns could lead him back to freedom.   
What We Need & What You Get
Have you ever known an abused woman? She will support the abuser, not the rescuer. She thinks supporting him will stop the beating and gain his love. The more he beats her the more support she has for him. If you call the police SHE will fight the police. If he leaves her she will find another just like him. The black community has suffered like an abused person. From slavery, Jim Crow, to the welfare system, we have been abused. But when any abused person gets enough, then watch out. We have had enough! The only way the abused person can really finally escape is to have a safe environment to rest and gather. “Tribalism” gives that abuse some light. story:
¿Qué?

Las increíbles aventuras de la Capitana Morgan confronta el entretenimiento e imaginación contra la superficialidad de una sociedad cada vez más preocupada por la imagen y el bienestar individual.

A María no le gusta estar en un colegio interno de chicas, por sus estrictas normas de convivencia y por el trato que recibe por parte de algunas profesoras. Preferiría que el mundo se asemejara un poco más al de las novelas de aventuras que tanto la cautivan. 

Para escapar de la rutina decide tomarse una semana libre por su cuenta, emprendiendo un viaje en el que se encontrará con todo tipo de personajes inverosímiles, como un gato dotado de poderes extraordinarios, situaciones comprometidas y emocionantes e, incluso, tratará de descifrar un enigma que llevaba muchísimo tiempo olvidado; descubriendo que, al final, realidad y fantasía son caras de la misma moneda.

¿Quiénes?

Tandaia es una joven editorial con voluntad de cambio, de dar la alternativa a autores que no la encuentran en otro lugar, con nuevas y refrescantes ideas como es el emplear una campaña preventa para valorar la aceptación y viabilidad de cada título.

De este modo eres tú, ahora que te estás planteando cómo colaborar, el que decide si la obra que te presentamos verá la luz pasando a formar parte de nuestro catálogo... porque consideramos al lector parte fundamental del proceso.

Hoy te presentamos a Daniel Vargas.

Nacido en Madrid en 1977. De día trabaja como ingeniero, y de noche se dedica a crear historias fantásticas, debido a una afición por los cómics y la literatura, con la que convive desde que era niño. De ella, han ido surgiendo todo tipo de historietas, relatos y cuentos a lo largo de los años.

Las increíbles aventuras de la Capitana Morgan es su primera novela, y una de las pocas obras que se las ha ingeniado para escapar del cajón de su escritorio y viajar más allá de su mundo de fantasía.

¿Por qué?

Por aquí un fragmento del texto, para daros motivos:

«Me preguntaba qué nos encontraríamos una vez llegásemos a Isla Rocosa. Si seríamos capaces de averiguar qué era lo que estaba sucediendo, ya que, tampoco íbamos a disponer de mucho tiempo una vez estuviéramos allí. Probablemente el éxito dependería de tener otro golpe de suerte, porque no parecía que la explicación de todo fuera a ser algo evidente, lógico y cotidiano.
     La opción extraterrestre era la que más me fascinaba, por ser, sin duda, la más increíble de todas las que imaginaba. Aunque, también me producía cierto temor, por el hecho de que pudiera terminar siendo abducida, ser sometida a terribles experimentos por todo el cuerpo o, peor aún, en la cabeza.
     Y al final, ser devuelta al mundo, con la memoria alterada y no poder recordar nada de lo ocurrido.
     Mi imaginación también proponía otras respuestas, tal vez, no tan increíbles, pero últimamente, tenía la impresión de que fantasía y realidad no se distanciaban tanto como siempre había pensado.
     Sin ir más lejos, tenía a escasos centímetros un gato que hablaba y que era capaz de cambiar de tamaño a voluntad. Si eso podía pasar, por qué no pensar que cualquier cosa podía ocurrir, sin límites ni estereotipos. Quién le iba a decir a alguien hace cien años que íbamos a poner el pie en la luna. O, hace veinte, que podías mandar una foto a cientos de personas con un teléfono móvil.
     También, me resultaba curioso el creciente interés de Pedro por recordar su primer viaje a la isla y que, de alguna manera, le había marcado tanto. Porque de no ser por ello, sería incomprensible que en el estado en el que se encontraba, fuese capaz de hacer el sobreesfuerzo que estaba realizando durante tanto tiempo. Tal vez, eso le pasase factura más adelante, pero habría que confiar en que todo saliera bien y, al final, regresásemos todos al puerto sanos y salvos»

¿Cómo?

Para arrancar el proyecto nos hemos fijado como objetivo 840€; esta es la cantidad que recaudaríamos si alrededor de cincuenta mecenas se hiciesen, cada cual, con un ejemplar de esta primera edición.

  • Teniendo acceso a las galeradas de edición.
  • Recibiendo un ejemplar semanas antes de la salida al mercado de la obra.
  • Si bien, también podrías ver tu nombre en los agradecimientos aportando un poco más.

Los fondos recaudados, se utilizarán como ayuda para sacar adelante esta primera edición de Las increíbles aventuras de la Capitana Morgan que saldría después a la venta.

Además...

Sabemos que son tiempos difíciles, también nosotros los sufrimos, y es posible que no te encuentres en disposición de apoyarnos con tu mecenazgo en estos momentos... pero esperamos que si esto te ha llegado al alma, incluso si tal vez conoces en persona al autor, trates de difundir esta campaña (facebook, twitter, blogger, boca-oreja... ) para que alcancemos nuestra meta y Daniel Vargas vea publicada su obra.

Gracias por vuestro tiempo.
